topics.title: Introduction and why strategy feels mystical
topics.summary: Chandra introduces the idea that product strategy is often treated as an innate talent (“strategy gene”), setting up the episode’s goal: making strategy repeatable and accessible.

topics.title: Episode setup and Chandra’s credentials
topics.summary: Lenny introduces Chandra’s background and frames the episode as an operator-friendly, five-step strategy process inspired by classic strategy frameworks.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor messages for Eppo (experimentation platform) and Airtable ProductCentral (product org system of record).

topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Lenny shares how a community recommendation led to inviting Chandra, and tees up the promise of a practical playbook for building strategy and alignment.

topics.title: Headspace origin story: strategy to create clarity
topics.summary: Chandra recounts how a CEO comment (“people don’t know why we’re working on this”) triggered building Headspace’s first written product strategy, leading to a major product reimagining and company trajectory shift.

topics.title: Who this playbook is for and why it works
topics.summary: Chandra explains this is an operator’s synthesis of established strategy thinking (Porter, Rumelt, Playing to Win), designed for product people who want a repeatable method; he’s iterated it across multiple companies including Meta.

topics.title: Defining product strategy: resonance, focus, and tradeoffs
topics.summary: They define strategy as the bridge between mission/vision and the plan/roadmap, emphasizing forced choices, explicit non-goals, and the “why,” using a resonance analogy to describe product-market fit.

topics.title: Process overview: 8–12 weeks and five phases
topics.summary: Chandra outlines the end-to-end strategy process (prep, strategy sprint, design sprint, doc writing, rollout), why it takes ~a quarter, and how to handle pressure for faster timelines.

topics.title: Preparation phase: working group and key inputs
topics.summary: They detail forming a cross-functional strategy working group and compiling a comprehensive prep readout: behavioral insights, UXR synthesis, leadership interviews (the “fruit” story), competitive analysis, adjacent roadmaps, and user observation for empathy.

topics.title: Strategy sprint: problem clustering to strategic pillars
topics.summary: In a 3–5 day sprint, the team shares prep findings, enumerates and clusters problems, reframes them as opportunities, and ranks them by impact, certainty, clarity of levers, and differentiation to select ~3 strategic pillars and define what not to focus on.

topics.title: How-might-we prompts and winning aspiration headline
topics.summary: They translate pillars into “how might we” questions to spark solutions, then craft a two-year “winning aspiration” using a newspaper-headline exercise (including an example from Meta’s privacy work) to clarify intended outcomes.

topics.title: Alignment benefits and moving into the design sprint
topics.summary: They discuss how the process creates shared clarity even when outcomes evolve during execution (“not confused”), then introduce the design sprint’s purpose: generate illustrative concepts (not final features) that make each pillar tangible and testable.
